field_edited_text.value:
APPROVED PARK PLAN PART OF THE MASTER PLAN
FOR THE CITY OF BALTIMORE: The latest revision of
the Master Park Plan, dated February 21, 1961, shows
clearly the contrast in realization to date of the three
major stream-valley parks—Gwynn’s Falls, Jones Falls
and Herring Run. The loss of the stream-valley con-
cept along the Jones Falls south of Bend Hill is evi-
dent. It is obvious from the illustration above, that
Baltimore made a fine start toward achievement of a
strong, green pattern woven into the City development.
The City and the County are but a short step away
from the ‘“humane city”’* that offers parks, open
squares and playing fields, sunlight, fresh air and free
movement, the sight of grass, bushes, flowers and trees
in addition to the technological necessities. One of the
demands of the future will be that cities be beautiful,
that living as well as working places be in attractive
surroundings, and that the increased public leisure
time be satisfied both close at hand as well as a few
hours’ drive away.

*as described by Lewis Mumford in “The Social Function of

Open Spaces,” a paper delivered to the International Federation
of Landscape Architects in Brussels, 1960.
